questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to the office with a 1-month history of low back pain. She does not recall any recent trauma. She works as a journalist and spends most of her time sitting at her desk. Examination in the prone position shows a deep sacral sulcus on the right side and a posterior inferior lateral angle (ILA) on the left side. When the patient is asked to bend forward in a seated position, the left posterior superior iliac spine (PSIS) moves superior. L5 is flexed, rotated right, and sidebent right. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While right unilateral sacral flexion also manifests with a deep sacral sulcus on the right, there would be a posterior ILA on the right, and a seated flexion test would be positive on the right. This patient presents with a deep sacral sulcus contralateral to a posterior inferior ILA, indicating sacral torsion rather than sacral flexion.

B) INCORRECT:

While left unilateral sacral flexion also manifests with a positive seated flexion test on the left and a posterior ILA on the left, the sacral sulcus would be deep on the left rather than right. This patient presents with a deep sacral sulcus contralateral to a posterior inferior ILA, indicating sacral torsion rather than sacral flexion.

C) INCORRECT:

While right-on-right sacral torsion, or right sacral rotation around a right oblique axis, also manifests with a seated flexion test positive on the left and L5 sidebent right, L5 would be in neutral position and rotated to the left. Additionally, right-on-right sacral torsion typically results in a deep sacral sulcus on the left and a posterior ILA on the right.

D) INCORRECT:

While right-on-left sacral torsion, or right sacral rotation around a left oblique axis, also manifests with L5 in nonneutral position (i.e., flexed or extended), L5 would be sidebent left and rotated left. Additionally, right-on-left sacral torsion typically results in a deep sacral sulcus on the left, a posterior ILA on the right, and a seated flexion test that is positive on the right.

E) CORRECT:

A deep sacral sulcus found contralateral to a posterior inferior ILA indicates sacral torsion, in which the sacrum rotates around an oblique axis. The oblique axis is on the right, which is indicated by both the positive seated flexion test on the left and L5 sidebent right. In sacral torsion, the sacrum and L5 are rotated in opposite directions, so, given that L5 is rotated right in this patient, the sacrum is rotated left. Taken together, this patient has left rotation around a right oblique axis, i.e.; left-on-right sacral torsion.
Image Description:

The sacrum rotates on an oblique axis, which is named after the sacral sulci it runs through. Sacral sulci and inferior lateral angles (ILAs) are pushed in opposite directions. In forward sacral torsion, rotation occurs on the same side of the axis (e.g., left rotation on left oblique axis). In backward sacral torsion, rotation occurs on the opposite side of the axis (e.g., left rotation on right oblique axis).
questions.hint: This patient presents with a positive seated flexion test on the left (i.e., left PSIS moves superior).

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, presents to the office because of persistent low back pain that started after the birth of her baby 2 weeks ago. She says that the pain intensifies when she sits or stands for a long time. Her pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. On examination, the sacral sulci are deep on both sides; the lumbosacral junction springs on compression in the prone position. When the patient is asked to bend forward while seated, there is equal movement of the posterior superior iliac spines bilaterally. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While right-on-right sacral torsion also manifests with a negative lumbosacral spring test and a deep sacral sulcus on the left, the sacral sulcus would be shallow on the right, and the seated flexion test would be positive on the left.

B) CORRECT:

A deep (i.e., anterior) sacral sulcus on both sides and findings of anterior displacement of the base of the sacrum (negative lumbosacral spring test) suggest bilateral sacral flexion, in which the sacrum rotates forward around the middle transverse axis. In bilateral flexion, the seated flexion test is falsely negative because both sacroiliac joints are restricted to movement. Additionally, in this type of torsion, the inferior lateral angles (ILAs) are posterior and inferior bilaterally. This condition is common in postpartum individuals.

C) INCORRECT:

While bilateral sacral extension also manifests with bilateral sacral sulcus displacement and a negative seated flexion test, the lumbosacral spring test would be positive.

D) INCORRECT:

While left-on-left sacral torsion also manifests with a negative lumbosacral spring test and a deep sacral sulcus on the right, the sacral sulcus would be shallow on the left, and the seated flexion test would be positive on the right.

E) INCORRECT:

While left-on-right sacral torsion also manifests with a deep sacral sulcus on the right, the left sacral sulcus would be shallow. Furthermore, the lumbosacral spring test would be positive, and the seated flexion test would be positive on the left.
questions.hint: This postpartum patient presents with a negative seated flexion test (i.e., equal movement of posterior superior iliac spine bilaterally) and a negative lumbosacral spring test (i.e., the lumbosacral junction springs back on compression).

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 10-day history of low back pain. She says that she has been preparing for a major ballet performance, training intensely for 8 hours every day. Acetaminophen and ice packs provide little relief. Her past medical history is significant for mild scoliosis diagnosed at the age of 15 years. She denies any trauma. On examination, the left sacral sulcus is shallow and the left inferior lateral angle (ILA) is superior. The lumbosacral junction does not spring back on compression. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Right unilateral sacral flexion is characterized by a right deep sacral sulcus and a posterior and inferior ILA on the right. In addition, lumbosacral spring test would be negative (i.e., the lumbosacral junction springs back on compression).

B) INCORRECT:

While a shallow sacral sulcus, ipsilateral ILA that is superior, and positive lumbosacral spring test are characteristic of unilateral sacral extension, these findings would be on the right rather than left side.

C) INCORRECT:

Left unilateral sacral flexion is characterized by a left deep sacral sulcus and a posterior and inferior ILA on the left. In addition, lumbosacral spring test would be negative (i.e., the lumbosacral junction springs back on compression).

D) CORRECT:

A posterior (i.e., shallow) sacral sulcus with an ipsilateral superior and anterior ILA indicates a unilateral flexion or extension dysfunction. A positive lumbosacral spring test is always pathological and suggests that the sacrum is in relative extension. Because these findings are on the left side of the sacrum, a left unilateral sacral extension can be diagnosed.

E) INCORRECT:

While a shallow sacral sulcus, ipsilateral ILA that is superior, and positive lumbosacral spring test are characteristic of sacral extension dysfunctions, findings in bilateral sacral extension would be on both sides rather than only on the left.
questions.hint: The absence of a spring on compression of the lumbosacral junction (positive lumbosacral spring test) is due to a sacral dysfunction that has led to reversed lordotic curvature of the lumbar spine.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old man presents to the office with a 1-week history of low back pain. He says that the pain started after he increased his weight for the deadlift during preparation for a powerlifting competition. He reports taking ibuprofen, which provided temporary pain relief. Physical examination reveals:

Shallow sacral sulcus on the right
Anterior inferior lateral angle (ILA) on the left
Positive seated flexion test on the right
L5 flexed, rotated left, sidebent left

The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Right-on-right sacral torsion, or right sacral rotation around a right oblique axis, manifests with a deep sacral sulcus on the left, a posterior ILA on the right, positive seated flexion test on the left, and L5 neutral, sidebent right, rotated left.

B) INCORRECT:

While left-on-right sacral torsion, or left sacral rotation around a right oblique axis, also manifests with L5 in nonneutral position (i.e., flexed or extended), L5 would be sidebent and rotated right. Additionally, left-on-right sacral torsion typically results in a shallow sacral sulcus on the left, anterior inferior lateral angle on the right, and seated flexion test positive on the left.

C) INCORRECT:

While unilateral sacral extension also manifests with an anterior inferior lateral angle on the left, the left sacral sulcus would be shallow rather than the right, and seated flexion test would be positive on the left.

D) INCORRECT:

Left-on-left sacral torsion, or left sacral rotation around a left oblique axis, manifests with a deep sacral sulcus on the right, a posterior ILA on the left, positive seated flexion test on the right, and L5 neutral, sidebent left, rotated right.

E) CORRECT:

A deep sacral sulcus found contralateral to a posterior inferior ILA indicates sacral torsion, in which the sacrum rotates around an oblique axis. The oblique axis is on the left, which is indicated by both the positive seated flexion test on the right and L5 sidebent left. In sacral torsion, the sacrum and L5 are rotated in opposite directions, so, given that L5 is rotated left in this patient, the sacrum is rotated right. Taken together, this patient has right rotation around a left oblique axis, i.e.; right-on-left sacral torsion.
Image Description:

The sacrum rotates on an oblique axis, which is named after the sacral sulci it runs through. Sacral sulci and inferior lateral angles (ILAs) are pushed in opposite directions. In forward sacral torsion, rotation occurs on the same side of the axis (e.g., left rotation on left oblique axis). In backward sacral torsion, rotation occurs on the opposite side of the axis (e.g., left rotation on right oblique axis).
questions.hint: On further examination, lumbosacral spring test is likely to be positive.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man presents to the office with a 2-month history of low back pain. Past medical history reveals hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and ankylosing spondylitis of the sacroiliac joint. The patient takes metformin and captopril. On examination, there is a deep sacral sulcus on the right and a posterior inferior lateral angle on the left. The patient is asked to lay in the prone position; there is springing on compression of the lumbosacral junction. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Left-on-right sacral torsion, or left sacral rotation around a right oblique axis, also manifests with a deep sacral sulcus on the right and a posterior inferior lateral angle on the left, but a lumbosacral spring test would be positive.

B) INCORRECT:

Right unilateral sacral flexion also manifests with deep sacral sulcus on the right and a negative lumbosacral spring test, but there would be a posterior inferior lateral angle (ILA) on the right rather than left.

C) CORRECT:

A deep sacral sulcus found contralaterally to a posterior inferior lateral angle (ILA) indicates sacral torsion, in which the sacrum is rotated on an oblique axis. This patient's sacral base is anterior, indicating forward sacral torsion (i.e., the sacrum is rotated toward the same side as the oblique axis). A patient with forward sacral torsion and a deep sacral sulcus on the right thus has left rotation around a left oblique axis, or left-on-left sacral torsion. This condition can be caused by tightening of the sacroiliac joint, e.g., in ankylosing spondylitis.
Image Description:

The sacrum rotates on an oblique axis, which is named after the sacral sulci it runs through. Sacral sulci and inferior lateral angles (ILAs) are pushed in opposite directions. In forward sacral torsion, rotation occurs on the same side of the axis (e.g., left rotation on left oblique axis). In backward sacral torsion, rotation occurs on the opposite side of the axis (e.g., left rotation on right oblique axis).

D) INCORRECT:

Left unilateral sacral extension manifests with a shallow sacral sulcus on the left, a superior and anterior inferior lateral angle (ILA) on the left, and a positive lumbosacral spring test.

E) INCORRECT:

Right-on-right sacral torsion, or right sacral rotation around a right oblique axis, also manifests with a negative lumbosacral spring test, but there would be a deep sacral sulcus on the left and a posterior inferior lateral angle on the right.
questions.hint: A negative spring test (i.e., the lumbosacral junction springs back on compression) indicates that the base of the sacrum has moved anterior.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman comes to the office with a 5-day history of low back pain. She mentions recently starting a new job that requires her to walk frequently throughout a large facility, often covering several miles a day. The pain does not radiate down her legs. She denies any history of trauma. Her only current medication is an oral contraceptive. Structural examination reveals:

Normal muscle strength, tone, and reflexes
Deeper left sacral sulcus compared to the right
Posterior inferior lateral angle on the right
Positive seated flexion test on the left

The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bilateral sacral extension manifests with a shallow sacral sulcus on both sides and anterior inferior lateral angle (ILA) on both sides.

B) INCORRECT:

Left-on-left sacral torsion, or left sacral rotation on a left oblique axis, manifests with positive seated flexion test on the right, deep sacral sulcus on the right, and posterior inferior lateral angle (ILA) on the left.

C) INCORRECT:

Left-on-right sacral torsion, or left sacral rotation around a right oblique axis, also manifests with positive seated test on the left, but sacral sulcus would be deep on the right and inferior lateral angle (ILA) would be posterior on the left.

D) CORRECT:

A deep sacral sulcus found contralaterally to a posterior inferior lateral angle (ILA) indicates sacral torsion, in which the sacrum is rotated on an oblique axis. The seated flexion test is positive on the contralateral side of the oblique axis, thus the sacrum is rotated around a right oblique axis. This patient has a deep left sacral sulcus, indicating forward sacral torsion (i.e., the sacrum is rotated toward the same side as the oblique axis). Taken together, this patient has right rotation around a right oblique axis, or right-on-right sacral torsion.
Image Description:

The sacrum rotates on an oblique axis, which is named after the sacral sulci it runs through. Sacral sulci and inferior lateral angles (ILAs) are pushed in opposite directions. In forward sacral torsion, rotation occurs on the same side of the axis (e.g., left rotation on left oblique axis). In backward sacral torsion, rotation occurs on the opposite side of the axis (e.g., left rotation on right oblique axis).

E) INCORRECT:

Right unilateral sacral flexion also manifests with right inferior lateral angle (ILA) that is posterior, but the deep sacral sulcus and positive seated flexion test would be on the right rather than left side.
questions.hint: On further examination, L5 would be neutral, sidebent right, and rotated left.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presents to the office with a 2-week history of recurrent low back pain. She mentions that she recently helped her friend move into a new apartment. Her medical history is remarkable for type 2 diabetes mellitus controlled with metformin. Examination reveals a deep sacral sulcus on the left and a posterior inferior lateral angle (ILA) on the right; there is no tenderness on palpation. Lumbosacral spring test is positive. L5 is flexed, rotated left, and sidebent left. The patient consents to receiving osteopathic manipulative treatment. Treatment with muscle energy involves positioning the patient in the

choices.text: right lateral Sims position with face down
left lateral Sims position with face down
right lateral recumbent position with face up
supine position with knees flexed at 90 degrees
left lateral recumbent position with face up

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A right lateral Sims position engages the right oblique axis and may be used to treat right-on-right sacral torsion. While right-on-right torsion manifests with a deep sacral sulcus on the left, and posterior ILA on the right, the sacrum is bent forward in this type of torsion and lumbosacral spring test would be negative.

B) INCORRECT:

A left lateral Sims position engages the left oblique axis and is used to treat left-on-left sacral torsion. This type of torsion manifests with a deep sacral sulcus on the right and posterior ILA on the left. Furthermore, left-on-left sacral torsion is a forward type of torsion and lumbosacral spring test would be negative. Although this position engages the left oblique axis, it is not appropriate for treating right-on-left sacral torsion.

C) INCORRECT:

A right lateral recumbent position with face up engages the right oblique axis and is used to treat left-on-right sacral torsion. While this backward type of torsion manifests with a positive lumbosacral spring test, the sacral sulcus would be deep on the right with posterior ILA on the left.

D) INCORRECT:

Supine position with knees flexed at 90 degrees is typically used for treating bilateral sacral flexion, which is characterized by rotation around the transverse axis. Diagnostic findings for bilateral sacral flexion include deep sacral sulci and a posterior ILA bilaterally. This position is not appropriate for treating sacral torsion, which is due to sacral rotation around an oblique axis.

E) CORRECT:

For osteopathic treatment of a sacral torsion, the patient lies with the oblique axis downward and on the opposite side to the sacral rotation, which in this patient is the left recumbent position. Forward sacral torsions are treated with the patient's face down, while backward sacral torsions are treated with the patient's back down. In a right-on-left sacral torsion or backward torsion, the left shoulder is pulled out to position the patient with their back down and face up. Then, the physician flexes the patient's hips until the motion at the lumbosacral junction is felt, and drops the legs off the table to induce left sidebending and engage the left oblique axis. The patient then lifts their legs against a counterforce applied by the physician. This isometric contraction induces reflective relaxation of the affected muscles, relieving the restrictive barrier and pain.
questions.hint: The combination of a deep sacral sulcus on the left; a right inferior lateral angle (ILA) that is posterior and inferior; an L5 that is flexed, sidebent left, and rotated left; and a positive lumbosacral spring test suggests right-on-left sacral torsion.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the office for a health maintenance examination. She feels well and reports no symptoms. She is a seamstress and spends most of the day sitting and working on her sewing machine. Her medical history is significant for hypothyroidism treated with levothyroxine. She is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 95 kg (209 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m2. The patient requests an osteopathic evaluation. Examination in the prone position reveals L5 in a neutral position. The sacral base moves posteriorly during inhalation and anteriorly during exhalation. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The sacral motion observed in this patient primarily occurs around which axis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The innominates, rather than the sacrum, rotate around the inferior transverse axis of the sacrum during ambulation. The sacrum itself does not rotate around the inferior transverse axis.

B) INCORRECT:

The sacrum rotates around the middle transverse axis during postural motions such as bending forward and backward.

C) CORRECT:

The sacrum rotates around the superior transverse axis during respiratory and craniosacral (inherent) motions. In respiratory motion, the base of the sacrum moves posteriorly during inhalation and anteriorly during exhalation. In craniosacral motion, the base of the sacrum moves posteriorly (counternutates) during flexion and anteriorly (nutates) during extension. The superior transverse axis is located at the level of the S2 vertebra and posterior to the sacroiliac joint.

D) INCORRECT:

The sacrum rotates around the oblique axes during dynamic motions such as ambulation. The right oblique sacral axis would be engaged during weight bearing on the right leg (e.g., stepping forward with the left leg) rather than during respiration.

E) INCORRECT:

The sacrum rotates around the oblique axes during dynamic motions such as ambulation. The left oblique sacral axis would be engaged during weight bearing on the left leg (e.g., stepping forward with the right leg) rather than during respiration.
questions.hint: This patient's examination findings show motion around the respiratory axis.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman presents to the office with a 5-day history of pelvic and thigh pain. She mentions that the pain began after she started a new workout routine that includes high-intensity running and cycling. She denies any history of trauma or falls. Structural examination reveals:


Anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) more superior on the left than the right

Posterior superior iliac spine (PSIS) more inferior on the left than the right
Positive standing flexion test on the right

The most likely somatic dysfunction is
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Posterior innominate rotations present with a positive standing flexion test, a superior ASIS, and an inferior PSIS on the side of the dysfunction.
Image Description:

ASIS: anterior superior iliac spine
PSIS: posterior superior iliac spine

B) INCORRECT:

Innominate inflares present with a positive standing flexion test, medially displaced ASIS, and laterally displaced ischial tuberosity on the side of the dysfunction. Innominate inflares do not cause superior or inferior displacement of the ASIS or PSIS, as seen in this patient.
Image Description:

ASIS: anterior superior iliac spine

C) INCORRECT:

In a superior innominate shear dsyfunction, the ASIS and PSIS of the affected innominate are superior to the ASIS and PSIS of the contralateral innominate. Although superior innominate shears lead to a positive standing flexion test, this patient's superior ASIS is contralateral to her superior PSIS, making a different diagnosis more likely.
Image Description:

ASIS: anterior superior iliac spine
PSIS: posterior superior iliac spine

D) INCORRECT:

Innominate outflares present with a positive standing flexion test, laterally displaced ASIS, and medially displaced ischial tuberosity on the side of the dysfunction. Innominate outflares do not cause superior or inferior displacement of the ASIS or PSIS, as seen in this patient.
Image Description:

ASIS: anterior superior iliac spine

E) CORRECT:

Innominate rotation occurs when one innominate is rotated anteriorly or posteriorly around a transverse axis. Palpatory findings in patients with anterior innominate rotation include an inferior ASIS and a superior PSIS on the side of the dysfunction compared to the other innominate. Because a contralateral posterior innominate rotation can yield similar static findings, it is necessary to perform a standing flexion test or an ASIS compression test to determine which side the dysfunction is on. This patient's standing flexion test is positive on the right, indicating an anterior innominate rotation on the right side. Hypertonicity of the rectus femoris of the quadriceps muscle can cause this dysfunction because of increased downward tension on its bony origin, the anterior inferior iliac spine.
Image Description:

ASIS: anterior superior iliac spine
PSIS: posterior superior iliac spine

F) INCORRECT:

Inferior pubic shears manifest with an inferior pubic bone on the side of the dysfunction. Typically, pubic shear dysfunctions cause localized pain in the pubic region and result from trauma to the anterior pelvis or added weight on the pubic bone during pregnancy. Although an inferior pubic shear would result in a positive standing flexion test, they are not consistent with superior displacement of the ASIS and inferior displacement of the PSIS, which is seen in this patient.
questions.hint: Tight quadriceps muscles are a common cause of this condition.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the office with a 2-week history of low back pain. She is a second-year osteopathic medicine student and says that over the past month, she has been sitting at her desk for longer than usual to prepare for an important exam. Physical examination reveals an anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) located inferiorly and a posterior superior iliac spine (PSIS) located superiorly on the left. Standing flexion test is positive on the left. Which of the following muscles will be primarily activated when treating this patient's dysfunction using direct muscle energy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thigh external rotator muscles such as the gluteus maximus are activated as part of the treatment of innominate outflare dysfunction. This muscle group is not directly involved in the treatment of AIRD.

B) INCORRECT:

Thigh abductor muscles such as gluteus medius and minimus are activated to treat innominate outflare dysfunction. This muscle group is not directly involved in the treatment of AIRD.

C) CORRECT:

Anterior innominate rotation dysfunction (AIRD) can result from hypertonicity of the ipsilateral hip flexors, such as the rectus femoris muscle, which pulls the innominate into anterior rotation. To treat AIRD with muscle energy, the hip extensors should be activated, which include the gluteus maximus muscle and hamstrings (biceps femoris, semitendinosus, and semimembranosus). During direct muscle energy treatment of AIRD, the patient is placed in the supine position. The physician flexes the patient's hip and knee to engage the restrictive barrier by inducing posterior rotation. The patient is then instructed to extend the hip against counterforce applied by the physician for 35 seconds to activate the hamstrings and bring the innominate back to a neutral position.
Image Description:

ASIS: anterior superior iliac spine
PSIS: posterior superior iliac spine

D) INCORRECT:

The quadriceps femoris muscle includes the rectus femoris muscle, which is a hip flexor activated in the treatment of posterior rather than anterior innominate rotation dysfunction.

E) INCORRECT:

Thigh adductor and internal rotator muscles are activated in the treatment of innominate inflare dysfunction. This muscle group is not directly involved in the treatment of AIRD.
questions.hint: Inferior ASIS and superior PSIS on the left together with an ipsilateral positive standing flexion test indicate left anterior innominate rotation dysfunction (AIRD).

questions.text:
A 39-year-old woman presents to the office with a 2-week history of groin and hamstring pain. She mentions that the pain began after she went on a long hike. She denies any history of trauma or falls. Structural examination reveals:


Anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) that is more superior on the left than the right

Posterior superior iliac spine (PSIS) that is more inferior on the left than the right
Positive standing flexion test on the left

To perform direct muscle energy treatment for this patient's somatic dysfunction, the initial patient positioning is supine with her

choices.text: left knee flexed and her left hip brought into internal rotation
left knee flexed and her left hip brought into external rotation
left leg hanging off the table and her left hip brought into extension
left leg lifted off the table and her left hip and knee brought into flexion

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Flexing the left knee and bringing the left hip into internal rotation is used to engage the restrictive barrier during muscle energy treatment of innominate outflare dysfunctions. This patient has a posterior innominate rotation dysfunction, for which a different initial patient positioning is indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

Flexing the left knee and bringing the left hip into external rotation is used to engage the restrictive barrier during muscle energy treatment of innominate inflare dysfunctions. This patient has a posterior innominate rotation dysfunction, for which a different initial patient positioning is indicated.

C) CORRECT:

Posterior innominate rotation dysfunction (PIRD) can result from hypertonicity of the ipsilateral hip extensors, such as the hamstrings, which pull the innominate into posterior rotation. To treat PIRD with muscle energy, the hip flexors should be activated, which includes the quadriceps muscle. During direct muscle energy treatment of PIRD, the patient is placed in the supine position with the affected leg hanging off the edge of the table. The physician extends the patient's hip to engage the restrictive barrier by inducing anterior rotation. The patient is then instructed to push the leg upward and flex the hip against an equal counterforce applied by the physician for 35 seconds to activate the quadriceps and bring the innominate back to a neutral position.
Image Description:

ASIS: anterior superior iliac spine
PSIS: posterior superior iliac spine

D) INCORRECT:

Lifting the left leg off the table and bringing the left hip and knee into flexion is used to engage the restrictive barrier during muscle energy treatment of anterior innominate rotation dysfunctions. This patient has a posterior innominate rotation dysfunction, for which a different initial patient positioning is indicated.
questions.hint: A positive standing flexion test on the left, combined with a superior ASIS and an inferior PSIS on the same side, indicates a left-sided posterior innominate rotation dysfunction.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of low back and groin pain that began after falling down a short flight of stairs 3 days ago. He reports no other injuries and no loss of consciousness during or after the fall. His past medical history is unremarkable, and he denies any bladder or bowel issues. Hip flexion and extension are unrestricted and painless. Structural examination reveals that the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS), posterior superior iliac spine (PSIS), and pubic ramus on the left side are inferior to those on the right side. The patient's right leg is shorter than his left. The left PSIS moves superiorly upon flexion of the spine from a standing position. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The standing flexion test is positive on the side of the dysfunction, which is the left side in this patient. Furthermore, the left ASIS, PSIS, and pubic bone are inferior to those on the right, indicating that the left innominate bone is displaced inferiorly to the right innominate bone. Inferior innominate shear dysfunctions lead to lengthening of the ipsilateral leg.
Image Description:

ASIS: anterior superior iliac spine
PSIS: posterior superior iliac spine

B) INCORRECT:

The standing flexion test is positive on the side of the dysfunction, which is the left rather than the right side in this patient. Furthermore, this patient's left pubic ramus is inferior to his right pubic ramus. Pubic shear dysfunctions do not affect the level of the ASIS and PSIS or cause a difference in leg length.

C) INCORRECT:

The standing flexion test is positive on the side of the dysfunction, which is the left rather than the right side in this patient. Furthermore, a right inferior innominate shear manifests with the right ASIS, PSIS, and pubic ramus displaced inferiorly to the left innominate bone, leading to a lengthened right leg.

D) INCORRECT:

The standing flexion test is positive on the side of the dysfunction, which is the left side in this patient. Although this patient's left pubic ramus is displaced, pubic shear dysfunctions do not affect the level of the ASIS and PSIS or cause a difference in leg length.

E) INCORRECT:

The standing flexion test is positive on the side of the dysfunction, which is the left side in this patient. However, this patient's left pubic ramus is inferior rather than superior to his right pubic ramus. Furthermore, pubic shear dysfunctions do not affect the level of the ASIS and PSIS or cause a difference in leg length.

F) INCORRECT:

Right superior innominate shear dysfunctions manifest with the right ASIS, PSIS, and pubic ramus displaced superiorly to the left innominate bone, causing a shortened right leg. Although the innominate asymmetry in this patient suggests a right superior innominate shear, his positive standing flexion test on the left side indicates that the dysfunction is on the left.
questions.hint: This patient has a positive standing flexion test on the left side.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman presents to the office with a 2-week history of intermittent dull low back pain after slipping on a wet floor. Past medical history is unremarkable. Her only medication is a multivitamin. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination in the prone position reveals:

Normal muscle strength, tone, and reflexes
Mild tenderness over the sacrotuberous ligament
Deep sacral sulcus on the right
Posterior inferior lateral angle (ILA) on the left
Lumbosacral junction that does not spring freely on compression
L5 flexed, rotated right, sidebent right

The most likely diagnosis is

choices.text: left sacral rotation around a left oblique axis
right sacral rotation around a left oblique axis
right unilateral sacral flexion around a transverse axis
right sacral rotation around a right oblique axis
left sacral rotation around a right oblique axis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While left sacral rotation around a left oblique axis, or left-on-left sacral torsion, also manifests with a deep sacral sulcus on the right, a posterior inferior lateral angle (ILA) on the left, and L5 rotated right, L5 would be in a neutral position and sidebent left. Additionally, lumbosacral spring test would be negative.

B) INCORRECT:

While right sacral rotation around a left oblique axis, or right-on-left sacral torsion, also manifests with a positive lumbosacral spring test and L5 in nonneutral position (i.e., flexed or extended), L5 would be sidebent and rotated left. Additionally, right-on-left sacral torsion typically results in a deep sacral sulcus on the left and a posterior lateral angle (ILA) on the right.

C) INCORRECT:

While right unilateral sacral flexion also manifests with a deep sacral sulcus on the right, the inferior lateral angle (ILA) would be posterior on the right rather than left, and lumbosacral spring test would be negative.

D) INCORRECT:

While right sacral rotation around a right oblique axis, or right-on-right sacral torsion, also manifests with L5 sidebent right, L5 would be in neutral position and rotated to the left. Additionally, right-on-right sacral torsion typically results in a deep sacral sulcus on the left, a posterior inferior lateral angle (ILA) on the right, and a negative lumbosacral spring test.

E) CORRECT:

A deep sacral sulcus found contralateral to a posterior inferior ILA indicates sacral torsion, in which the sacrum rotates around an oblique axis. The oblique axis is on the right, which is indicated by L5 sidebent right. In sacral torsion, the sacrum and L5 are rotated in opposite directions, so, given that L5 is rotated right in this patient, the sacrum is rotated left. Taken together, this patient has left rotation around a right oblique axis, i.e.; left-on-right sacral torsion.
Image Description:

The sacrum rotates on an oblique axis, which is named after the sacral sulci it runs through. Sacral sulci and inferior lateral angles (ILAs) are pushed in opposite directions. In forward sacral torsion, rotation occurs on the same side of the axis (e.g., left rotation on left oblique axis). In backward sacral torsion, rotation occurs on the opposite side of the axis (e.g., left rotation on right oblique axis).
questions.hint: A positive lumbosacral spring test (i.e., the sacrum does not spring back on compression) indicates that the base of the sacrum has moved posteriorly.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman presents to the office with a 2-week history of hip pain. The pain is dull, constant, and worsens with prolonged sitting. She has been taking ibuprofen with minimal relief. The patient denies any recent trauma or injuries but mentions that she recently began a new exercise regimen that includes cycling and jogging. Structural examination reveals:


Left anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) 3 cm from umbilicus


Right ASIS 5 cm from umbilicus

Left ischial tuberosity 5 cm from umbilicus
Right ischial tuberosity 3 cm from umbilicus
Positive standing flexion test on the left

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Innominate outflare is a dysfunction in which one innominate has rotated laterally around a vertical axis, causing the ipsilateral ASIS to move farther from the umbilicus than the contralateral ASIS. Therefore, in a left innominate outflare, the left ASIS can be palpated farther from the umbilicus (i.e., more lateral) than the right ASIS, and the left ischial tuberosity is closer to the umbilicus (i.e., more medial) than the right. This patient's left ASIS is closer to the umbilicus than his right ASIS, and his left ischial tuberosity is more lateral than his right.
Image Description:

ASIS: anterior superior iliac spine

B) INCORRECT:

Innominate inflare is a dysfunction in which one innominate has rotated medially around a vertical axis causing the ipsilateral ASIS to move closer to the umbilicus than the contralateral ASIS. In a right innominate inflare, the right ASIS can be palpated closer to the umbilicus (i.e., more medial) than the right ASIS, and the right ischial tuberosity is farther from the umbilicus (i.e., more lateral) than the left. This patient's right ASIS is farther from the umbilicus than his left ASIS, and his right ischial tuberosity is more medial than his left. Furthermore, if the dysfunction were on the right side, the positive standing flexion test would be positive on the right rather than the left.
Image Description:

ASIS: anterior superior iliac spine

C) INCORRECT:

Posterior innominate rotation is a dysfunction in which one innominate has rotated posteriorly relative to the sacrum. In a left posterior innominate rotation, the left ASIS can be palpated more superiorly than the right ASIS.
Image Description:

ASIS: anterior superior iliac spine
PSIS: posterior superior iliac spine

D) INCORRECT:

Innominate outflare is a dysfunction in which one innominate has rotated laterally around a vertical axis, causing the ipsilateral ASIS to move farther from the umbilicus than the contralateral ASIS. Therefore, in a right innominate outflare, the right ASIS can be palpated farther from the umbilicus (i.e., more lateral) than the left ASIS, and the right ischial tuberosity is closer to the umbilicus (i.e., more medial) than the left. This patient's right ASIS is farther from the umbilicus than his left ASIS, and his right ischial tuberosity is more medial than his left. However, his positive standing flexion test indicates a dysfunction on the left side.
Image Description:

ASIS: anterior superior iliac spine

E) INCORRECT:

Posterior innominate rotation is a dysfunction in which one innominate has rotated posteriorly relative to the sacrum. In a right posterior innominate rotation, the right ASIS can be palpated more superiorly than the left ASIS.
Image Description:

ASIS: anterior superior iliac spine
PSIS: posterior superior iliac spine

F) CORRECT:

Innominate inflare is a dysfunction in which one innominate has rotated medially around a vertical axis causing the ipsilateral ASIS to move closer to the umbilicus than the contralateral ASIS. In addition, the ischial tuberosity has shifted farther from the umbilicus on the affected side, and the ipsilateral posterior superior iliac spine (PSIS) is normal or slightly lateral in comparison to the contralateral PSIS. Therefore, in a left innominate inflare, the left ASIS can be palpated closer to the umbilicus (i.e., more medial) than the right ASIS. The left ischial tuberosity is farther from the umbilicus (i.e., more lateral) than the right, and the left PSIS is normal or slightly lateral in comparison to the right. Standing flexion test and ASIS compression test are both positive on the left side. An innominate inflare dysfunction is typically caused by muscle imbalance (e.g., due to prolonged sitting) or trauma and often occurs in combination with an anterior innominate rotation dysfunction. An innominate inflare may result in an internally rotated leg.
Image Description:

ASIS: anterior superior iliac spine
questions.hint: This patient has a condition that is usually caused by muscle imbalances and often occurs in combination with another innominate dysfunction.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 3-week history of pelvic pain that is more prominent on the left side. The pain occasionally radiates down her left leg and is exacerbated by prolonged sitting. The patient mentions that she has been cycling more frequently as part of a new exercise regimen. She denies any recent injury or trauma. She has been taking acetaminophen with minimal relief. Structural examination reveals that the left anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) is closer to the umbilicus than the right and that the left and right posterior superior iliac spines (PSIS) are equidistant from the umbilicus. The ASIS compression test is positive on the left. The patient consents to direct muscle energy treatment. Treatment with postisometric relaxation involves instructing the patient to perform which movement after the restrictive barrier has been engaged?

choices.text: Abduction and external rotation of the left hip
Adduction and internal rotation of the left hip
Abduction and internal rotation of the left hip

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Abduction and external rotation of the left leg against a counterforce applied by the physician activates the left abductors and external rotators of the hip. This describes the use of postisometric relaxation to treat a left innominate outflare dysfunction, which this patient does not have.

B) CORRECT:

To treat a left innominate inflare using postisometric relaxation, the left hip is initially positioned in abduction and external rotation to engage the restrictive barrier. Then, the patient adducts and internally rotates the hip (i.e., in the direction of ease) while the physician applies equal counterforce to achieve isometric contraction of the adductors and internal rotators of the hip. The contraction is held for approximately 5 seconds before relaxation, followed by reassessment of the dysfunction. Postisometric relaxation is an active, direct muscle energy technique that utilizes isometric contraction to trigger the Golgi tendon reflex, leading to reflexive relaxation and lengthening of the affected muscle.
Image Description:

ASIS: anterior superior iliac spine

C) INCORRECT:

After the restrictive barrier is engaged, the patient must move the left hip in the direction of ease against equal counterforce applied by the physician. Although internal rotation is the direction of ease in this patient's dysfunction, abduction is not.

D) INCORRECT:

Flexion of the left leg against a counterforce applied by the physician activates the quadriceps. This describes the use of postisometric relaxation to treat a left posterior innominate rotation dysfunction, which this patient does not have.

E) INCORRECT:

Extension of the left leg against a counterforce applied by the physician activates the hamstrings. This describes the use of postisometric relaxation to treat a left anterior innominate rotation dysfunction, which this patient does not have.
questions.hint: A medially displaced left ASIS and a normally positioned PSIS combined with a positive ASIS compression test on the left indicate a left innominate inflare.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the office with a 1-month history of pelvic pain. He mentions that he recently changed his running route, which now includes more uneven dirt trails. The patient denies any recent injury or trauma. Structural examination reveals a broader distance between the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) and the midline on the right than on the left. ASIS compression test is positive on the right. The right ischial tuberosity is tender to palpation and more medial ipsilaterally than the left ischial tuberosity. The patient consents to receiving muscle energy treatment. Treatment of this patient with direct muscle energy involves initially positioning the right hip in
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's positive ASIS compression test on the right, laterally displaced right ASIS, and medially displaced right ischial tuberosity indicate a right innominate outflare. Direct muscle energy involves initial patient positioning to engage the restrictive barrier of the dysfunction, which in innominate outflare is achieved with passive adduction and internal rotation of the hip. The patient is then instructed to contract the hip abductors against a counterforce applied by the physician.
Image Description:

ASIS: anterior superior iliac spine

B) INCORRECT:

Flexion of the hip engages the restrictive barrier in anterior innominate rotation dysfunction, which this patient does not have.

C) INCORRECT:

Extension of the hip engages the restrictive barrier in posterior innominate rotation dysfunction, which this patient does not have.

D) INCORRECT:

Abduction and external rotation are used to treat this patient's dysfunction during the active part of direct muscle energy treatment (i.e., when the patient is instructed to contract against counterforce). However, this is not the correct initial position because it would not engage the restrictive barrier. This position engages the restrictive barrier in innominate inflare dysfunction, which this patient does not have.

E) INCORRECT:

Abduction and internal rotation of the hip combined with inferior traction to the leg is the initial patient positioning to treat a superior innominate shear dysfunction, which this patient does not have.
questions.hint: Treatment with direct muscle energy involves initially positioning the body to engage the restrictive barrier.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old woman presents to the office with a 1-month history of low back pain. She does not recall any recent trauma. She works as a journalist and spends most of her time sitting at her desk. Physical examination in the prone position shows a deep sacral sulcus on the right side and a posterior inferior lateral angle (ILA) on the left side. Findings of a test performed during the examination are shown in the exhibit (without audio). L5 is flexed, rotated right, and sidebent right. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Video
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While right-on-right sacral torsion, or right sacral rotation around a right oblique axis, also manifests with a seated flexion test positive on the left and L5 sidebent right, L5 would be in neutral position and rotated to the left. Additionally, right-on-right sacral torsion typically results in a deep sacral sulcus on the left and a posterior ILA on the right.

B) INCORRECT:

While right-on-left sacral torsion, or right sacral rotation around a left oblique axis, also manifests with L5 in nonneutral position (i.e., flexed or extended), L5 would be sidebent left and rotated left. Additionally, right-on-left sacral torsion typically results in a deep sacral sulcus on the left, a posterior ILA on the right, and a seated flexion test that is positive on the right.

C) CORRECT:

A deep sacral sulcus found contralateral to a posterior inferior ILA indicates sacral torsion, in which the sacrum rotates around an oblique axis. The oblique axis is on the right, which is indicated by both the positive seated flexion test on the left and L5 sidebent right. In sacral torsion, the sacrum and L5 are rotated in opposite directions, so, given that L5 is rotated right in this patient, the sacrum is rotated left. Taken together, this patient has left rotation around a right oblique axis, i.e.; left-on-right sacral torsion.
Image Description:

The sacrum rotates on an oblique axis, which is named after the sacral sulci it runs through. Sacral sulci and inferior lateral angles (ILAs) are pushed in opposite directions. In forward sacral torsion, rotation occurs on the same side of the axis (e.g., left rotation on left oblique axis). In backward sacral torsion, rotation occurs on the opposite side of the axis (e.g., left rotation on right oblique axis).

D) INCORRECT:

While right unilateral sacral flexion also manifests with a deep sacral sulcus on the right, there would be a posterior ILA on the right, and a seated flexion test would be positive on the right. This patient presents with a deep sacral sulcus contralateral to a posterior inferior ILA, indicating sacral torsion rather than sacral flexion.

E) INCORRECT:

While left unilateral sacral flexion also manifests with a positive seated flexion test on the left and a posterior ILA on the left, the sacral sulcus would be deep on the left rather than right. This patient presents with a deep sacral sulcus contralateral to a posterior inferior ILA, indicating sacral torsion rather than sacral flexion.
questions.hint: In the exhibit, the patient undergoes a seated flexion test, which is positive on the left (i.e., left PSIS moves superior).

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with low back and groin pain that began after falling down a short flight of stairs 3 days ago. She reports no other injuries and no loss of consciousness during or after the fall. Her past medical history is unremarkable, and she denies any bladder or bowel issues. Hip flexion and extension are unrestricted and painless. Structural examination reveals that the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS), posterior superior iliac spine (PSIS), and pubic ramus on the left side are inferior to those on the right side. The patient's right leg is shorter than her left. Findings of a test performed during the examination are shown in the exhibit (without audio). What is the most likely diagnosis?
Video
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The standing flexion test is positive on the side of the dysfunction, which is the left side in this patient. However, this patient's left pubic ramus is inferior rather than superior to his right pubic ramus. Furthermore, pubic shear dysfunctions do not affect the level of the ASIS and PSIS or cause a difference in leg length.

B) INCORRECT:

The standing flexion test is positive on the side of the dysfunction, which is the left rather than the right side in this patient. Furthermore, a right inferior innominate shear manifests with the right ASIS, PSIS, and pubic ramus displaced inferiorly to the left innominate bone, leading to a lengthened right leg.

C) INCORRECT:

The standing flexion test is positive on the side of the dysfunction, which is the left side in this patient. Although this patient's left pubic ramus is displaced, pubic shear dysfunctions do not affect the level of the ASIS and PSIS or cause a difference in leg length.

D) INCORRECT:

The standing flexion test is positive on the side of the dysfunction, which is the left rather than the right side in this patient. Furthermore, this patient's left pubic ramus is inferior to his right pubic ramus. Pubic shear dysfunctions do not affect the level of the ASIS and PSIS or cause a difference in leg length.

E) CORRECT:

The standing flexion test is positive on the side of the dysfunction, which is the left side in this patient. Furthermore, the left ASIS, PSIS, and pubic bone are inferior to those on the right, indicating that the left innominate bone is displaced inferiorly to the right innominate bone. Inferior innominate shear dysfunctions lead to lengthening of the ipsilateral leg.
Image Description:

ASIS: anterior superior iliac spine
PSIS: posterior superior iliac spine

F) INCORRECT:

Right superior innominate shear dysfunctions manifest with the right ASIS, PSIS, and pubic ramus displaced superiorly to the left innominate bone, causing a shortened right leg. Although the innominate asymmetry in this patient suggests a right superior innominate shear, his positive standing flexion test on the left side indicates that the dysfunction is on the left.
questions.hint: In the exhibit, the patient undergoes a standing flexion test, which is positive on the left (i.e., left PSIS moves superior).
